Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Situation2: A routine service is held, and attendance numbers are usually sufficient even if one person is absent.
Story: I sat on the edge of my bed, phone pressed to my ear, listening to my stepbrother’s shaky voice. He’d just found out his mom was seriously ill, and I could hear the fear in every word. I wanted to be there for him, to sit with him, to let him know he wasn’t alone. That’s what we promised each other when our parents married—no matter what, we’d have each other’s backs. But as I glanced at the clock, my heart twisted. It was almost time for Friday night services at synagogue. My family expects me to go, and I know how important it is to keep that tradition, to show up and be counted, especially as a sign of respect for our faith. I could hear my mom downstairs, already calling for me to get ready. I felt torn in two—one part of me desperate to comfort my stepbrother, the other pulled by the weight of my Jewish identity and the expectations that come with it. My hands trembled as I tried to figure out what to do, feeling the pressure of both worlds closing in.
